title: Mount Astley
text:
Mount Astley is a <a href="mountain">mountain</a> summit located in the <a href="Palliser%20Range">Palliser Range</a> of the <a href="Canadian%20Rockies">Canadian Rockies</a> in <a href="Alberta">Alberta</a>, <a href="Canada">Canada</a>. It is situated in <a href="Banff%20National%20Park">Banff National Park</a> above <a href="Lake%20Minnewanka">Lake Minnewanka</a>. It was named after Charles D'Oyley Astley, who ran the boat concession on the lake in the late 1800s.
Geology.
Mount Astley is composed of <a href="sedimentary%20rock">sedimentary rock</a> laid down during the <a href="Precambrian">Precambrian</a> to <a href="Jurassic">Jurassic</a> periods. Formed in shallow seas, this sedimentary rock was pushed east and over the top of younger rock during the <a href="Laramide%20orogeny">Laramide orogeny</a>.
Climate.
Based on the <a href="K%C3%B6ppen%20climate%20classification">Köppen climate classification</a>, Mount Astley is located in a <a href="subarctic%20climate">subarctic climate</a> with cold, snowy winters, and mild summers. Temperatures can drop below −20 °C with wind chill factors below −30 °C. Precipitation <a href="Surface%20runoff">runoff</a> from Mount Astley drains into tributaries of the <a href="Bow%20River">Bow River</a>.
